prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: Region A: B7 continuum
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: A 20" x 20" mosaic imaging of 350 GHz continuum emission of Region A, with both of the 12m and 7m arrays.

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText: For the continuum observation, we utilise the full available bandwidth (default continuum setup, 1875 MHz wide with channel width of 31.25 MHz) for maximum sensitivity.

From the Herschel-PACS 70 micron data, this source has an angular size of ~11 arcsec. We proposal mosaic imaging of a 20" x 20" field with position angle of 21 degree to properly cover the source, with a spatial resolution of 0.7 arcsec to resolve the fragmentation at a scale of 900 AU. Due to the largest structure is at the size of 11 arcsec, ACA is required to recover the extended emissions.

Based on APEX LABOCA data, the continuum peak flux is 13 Jy/beam at a resolution of 19.2 arcsec. With a large fraction of the larger spatial scale emssion is filtered out, we estimated the continuum peak flux is ~ 1 Jy/beam at Band 7. We also aim to detect the low-mass components/fragments of this source, thus we propose a rms of 0.5 mJy, which gives a 5 sigma mass limit of 0.01 solar mass assumming dust temperature of 24 K. From the sensitivity calculator, 1.09 h (12m and 7m arrays)is needed to achieve this rms level.

prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: Region A: B3 molecular lines and continuum - A
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: Observation of N2H+, CH3CN, SO2 and continuum emission of Region A.

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText: Based on the Mopra data, the line width is ~ 3 km/s, a spectral resolution of 0.4 km/s is fine enough to resolve the lines, and any asymetric structure in the line profiles for further analysis with radiative transfer modelling. Any furher smoothing of the line resolution will 'smooth' out changes in the line profile shape due to dynamics such as infall. For the continuum observation, we utilise the whole available bandwidth (1875 MHz) to maximise the sensitivity.

Based on Herschel-PACS 70 micron image, the source has a angular size of 11 arcsec, our goal is to derive the physical properties and gas structure of the protostellar objects, thus we ask for a resolution of 1.4 arcsec which equates to 1800 AU at 1.3 kpc, the distance of the source.

Based on the Mopra observations of the 3 mm lines, the expected peak line flux density per beam is of 70 mJy, thus we ask for a rms of 7 mJy (0.4 K) for reliable detection of weaker gas emission (17 S/N). For a spectral resolution of ~0.3 km/s and bandwidth of ~330 km/s, the sensitivity calculator estimated a total of 34.9 min required to achieve this level of rms.
For the continuum, we expect a peak flux density of 7 mJy, with the integration time needed for the line observation, a rms of 50 uJy is achieved giving 138 S/N.

prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: Region A: B6 molecular lines and continuum
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: A 23" x 21" mosaic imaging of SiO, N2D+, and continuum emission of Region A.

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText: Based on the Mopra observations the 3 mm lines, the line width is ~ 3 km/s, we expect a similar value for the higher transitions, a spectral resolution of 0.3 km/s is fine enough to resolve the lines, and any asymetric structure in the line profile for further analysis with radiative transfer modelling. Any furher smoothing of the line resolution will 'smooth' out changes in the line profile shape due to dynamicas such as infall and outflows. For the continuum observation, we utilise the whole available bandwidth (1875 MHz) to maximise the sensitivity.

From Herschel 70 micron image, the source has an angular size of 11 arcsec, our goal is to derive the physical properties and structure of the high dense gas around the protostellar objects, thus we require a resolution of 0.7 arcsec which equates to 900 AU. We proposal mosaic imaging of a 23" x 21" field to properly cover the source.

Extrapolating the Mopra observations of the 3 mm lines, the expected peak line flux density is of ~30 mJy for line transitions at Band 6 frequency. For a spectral resolution of ~0.3 km/s (the finest setup), the sensitivity calculator estimated a total of 41.13 min required to achieve a rms of 8.6 mJy (0.4 K).
For the continuum, we expect a peak flux density of 0.2 Jy/beam (based on APEX-LABOCA data taking into account of larger spatial scale flux lost), with the integration time required for the line observation, a rms of 6 mJy is achieved.

prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: Region A: B3 molecular lines and continuum - B
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: Observation of HCO+, H13CO+, SiO, CS, and continuum of Region A.

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText: Based on the Mopra observations of HCO+ and SiO, the line width is ~ 6 km/s, while CS has a expected line width of 3 km/s, a spectral resolution of ~0.4 km/s is fine enough to resolve the lines, and any asymetric structure in the line profile for further analysis with radiative transfer modelling. Any furher smoothing of the line resolution will 'smooth' out changes in the line profile shape due to dynamics such as infall and outflows. For the continuum observation, we utilise the whole available bandwidth to maximise the sensitivity.

From Herschel 70 micron image, the source has an angular size of 11 arcsec. Similar to the other Band 3 science goal, our aim is to derive the physical properties and gas structure of the protostellar objects, thus we ask for a resolution of 1.4 arcsec which equates to 1800 AU.

Based on the Mopra observations of the 3 mm lines, the expected peak line flux density per beam is of ~70 mJy. With the HCO+ and SiO emission lines, we aim to derive the outflow properties of the protostellar objects, and thus requires a higher sensitivity setup than the other Band 3 science goal, at a rms of 2.4 mJy (0.2 K) to detect the line wings of these emission lines. For a spectral resolution of ~0.4 km/s, the sensitivity calculator estimated a total of 2.5 h is required to achieve this level of rms.
For the continuum, we expect a peak flux density of 7 mJy, with the integration time required for the line observation, a rms of 17 uJy is achieved.

prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: Region B: B7 continuum
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: A 20" x 20" mosaic imaging of 350 GHz continuum emission of Region B, with both of the 12m and 7m arrays.

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText: For the continuum observation, we utilise the full available bandwidth (default continuum setup, 1875 MHz wide with channel width of 31.25 MHz) for maximum sensitivity.

From the Herschel-PACS 70 micron data, this source has an angular size of ~11 arcsec. With a large fraction of the larger spatial scale emssion is filtered out, we estimated the continuum peak flux is ~ 1 Jy/beam at Band 7. We also aim to detect the low-mass components/fragments of this source, thus we propose a rms of 0.5 mJy, which gives a 5 sigma mass limit of 0.01 solar mass assumming dust temperature of 24 K. From the sensitivity calculator, 1.09 h (12m and 7m arrays) is needed to achieve this rms level.

prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: Region B: B3 molecular lines and continuum - B
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: Observation of HCO+, H13CO+, SiO, CS, and continuum of Region B.

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText: Based on the Mopra observations of HCO+ and SiO, the line width is ~ 6 km/s, while CS has a expected line width of 3 km/s, a spectral resolution of ~0.4 km/s is fine enough to resolve the lines, and any asymetric structure in the line profile for further analysis with radiative transfer modelling. From Herschel 70 micron image, the source has an angular size of 11 arcsec. Similar to the other Band 3 science goal, our aim is to derive the physical properties and gas structure of the protostellar objects, thus we ask for a resolution of 1.4 arcsec which equates to 1800 AU.

Based on the Mopra observations of the 3 mm lines, the expected peak line flux density per beam is of ~70 mJy. prp:ObsProposal.prp:abstract: Two scenarii are proposed for the formation of high mass stars: strong accretion with a high degree of turbulence or competitive accretion. These two scenarii can be distinguished during early phases of high-mass star formation by looking at the fragmentation and dynamical processes at high resolution in the millimeter. Recent ALMA and PdBI results show either a high degree of fragmentation or filaments' collision converging on a high mass core as physical processes observed towards high mass stars. We suggest that the leading mechanism might depend on the evolutionary stage of the source and on its immediate environment. We propose to test this hypothesis by observing with ALMA Band~3, 6, and 7 the continuum and line emissions towards two massive young sources located at the edges the RCW~120 Galactic HII region, in the highest column density part of its photodissociation region. These sources (0 and 38 in regions A and B) are in different evolutionary stage and live in different environments. With the ALMA data we will characterize their true spatial structure, derive their physical conditions and their velocity structure to identify the mechanisms that drive their formation.
prp:ObsProposal.prp:previousProposals: 2012.1.00892.S "Fragmentation of a massive pre-stellar object" J. Rodon
